snippet.textDisplay:
I like hydrogen cars above battery cars.

Elon Musk is another businessman appearing as a 'niceguy' - batteries are environmentally disastrous, what will we do with all the old batteries?

We can install wind turbines and solar panels at hydrogen filling stations - honestly, why is this not a thing yet?

snippet.textDisplay:
You can dispense hydrogen from the existing fuel stations? How on earth? Transportation of Hydrogen isn't as easy as pumping it in the truck at the factory, drive to the fuel station, pump it into the tank of the fuel station.
trucks can transport less than a tenth of hydrogen compared to regular fuel. Pipelines are a bad idea too, as they'll loose a lot of hydrogen on the way.
On bigger scales, hydrogen has to be produced at the fuel station and that needs a heckton of power
snippet.textOriginal:
You can dispense hydrogen from the existing fuel stations? How on earth? Transportation of Hydrogen isn't as easy as pumping it in the truck at the factory, drive to the fuel station, pump it into the tank of the fuel station.
trucks can transport less than a tenth of hydrogen compared to regular fuel. Pipelines are a bad idea too, as they'll loose a lot of hydrogen on the way.
On bigger scales, hydrogen has to be produced at the fuel station and that needs a heckton of power

snippet.textDisplay: How far have you to drive your H2 car to the next H2 station to fill it up? Do you know that these H2 station need around 10 min to recover for the next car? How many cars can be filled up with in a hour? Do you know how much such a H2 Station costs? How much does it cost to operate? What are the similar costs for a AC or DC Charger? Chargers can be placed at parking lots, doesn't waste extra space. Do you know that H2 Stations have to placed outside of residential areas? Do you know why? :)

snippet.textDisplay: Outside of Western Europe? As it stands now you can not drive from one side of America or South America top to bottom or Australia or Eastern Europe with an all Electric Car in anything remotely reasonable never mind almost all of Africa. You might as well be burning coal dust or have a steam powered car. Just look at what the "Green" industry did to Spain. When I can make a 1200 mile trip in 12 hours including recharging we can revisit all electric. Seriously though we need to be able to do at least 330 miles which is 55 mph x 6 hours of driving and we should be able to do it while pulling a 1500lbs. trailer through the mountains on a single charge. That is not at all extreme and is rather tame for a gasoline of diesel powered car in America. It needs to be fully recharged in 30 minutes so that it can be done at a rest stop or large gas station while you freshen up and grab a bite to eat. That is the bar minimum of acceptable range and usage anything less than that and it is might as well be an inner city only car for those people that live in old mega cities on the coasts. Range, Towing, Hauling, Recharge time, availability of parts so I can repair it myself, Toyota legendary durability are what I think of as the bare minimums. In many ways a Trendy Tesla is a step backwards!
snippet.textOriginal: Outside of Western Europe? When I can make a 1200 mile trip in 12 hours including recharging we can revisit all electric. Seriously though we need to be able to do at least 330 miles which is 55 mph x 6 hours of driving and we should be able to do it while pulling a 1500lbs. trailer through the mountains on a single charge. That is not at all extreme and is rather tame for a gasoline of diesel powered car in America. It needs to be fully recharged in 30 minutes so that it can be done at a rest stop or large gas station while you freshen up and grab a bite to eat. In many ways a Trendy Tesla is a step backwards!

snippet.textDisplay: There is a future for both technologies. Hydrogen for larger SUV's, trucks, heavy transport. And pure EV's and hybrids for smaller vehicles. I think hybrids are the future, especially if someone creates this super battery they have been dreaming of the last 30 years. Imagine having a 50Kwh battery for regular trips, and a diesel engine for those longer trips, extra heat in the winter, or just for those days the car didn't charge over night.
snippet.textOriginal: There is a future for both technologies. Hydrogen for larger SUV's, trucks, heavy transport. And pure EV's and hybrids for smaller vehicles. I think hybrids are the future, especially if someone creates this super battery they have been dreaming of the last 30 years. Imagine having a 50Kwh battery for regular trips, and a diesel engine for those longer trips, extra heat in the winter, or just for those days the car didn't charge over night.

snippet.textDisplay: I think you hi the nail on the head at the end; the most important quesion for witch car will be the future will be: "What will gas stations do?" If they, like now here in Blgium, do nothing; well then gogo baterycars. But if they deside to invest masavely in hydrogenpomps; then those cars (could) make it faster. But I'm a hughe fan off Tesla, and for me the top reason to go for baterycars is you can charge at home! And yes, there is the question what to do if you can't charge at home, well only these people will have to make a dissision witch car is the best for them. Can they charge at work, or near home, then maybe batery still can win. Also the "new" baterys are comming soon, so maybe they'll can go a week without charging there car, and have a chargestation in use with 6 or 7 other people and charge 1 night a week. The possebilatys are endless, so only the future will have the awnser. But still a great video.

snippet.textDisplay: well.. just dropping my two cents, batteries sucks, heavy, probably won't be much better in the near decade (or two..., because, electricity physics reasons), H2... don't even get me started about it, it's just the most unstable element we know, has the widest UEL-LEL range, it's way to costly to break it out of gas (gas, not gasoline) or water, has to be cryo (boiling temp is... 243C, negative) and compressed to 700 to 1200bar of pressure... IMHO, the best, was to combine both worlds, to avoid having an ev shopping cart for the daily commute (expensive shopping cart) and a car for travelling, moving away from diesel, is one heck of a big mistake, and those raising their fists against oil companies, are just doing them a favor to switch to BEV, H2EV or gasoline. Hauling those materials around the world, will need more ships in the sea, hauling batteries, new and used, will need more fuel too. Oil companies never get screwed by any means of fueling your car. Think about it.
snippet.textOriginal: well.. just dropping my two cents, batteries sucks, heavy, probably won't be much better in the near decade (or two..., because, electricity physics reasons), H2... don't even get me started about it, it's just the most unstable element we know, has the widest UEL-LEL range, it's way to costly to break it out of gas (gas, not gasoline) or water, has to be cryo (boiling temp is... 243C, negative) and compressed to 700 to 1200bar of pressure... IMHO, the best, was to combine both worlds, to avoid having an ev shopping cart for the daily commute (expensive shopping cart) and a car for travelling, moving away from diesel, is one heck of a big mistake, and those raising their fists against oil companies, are just doing them a favor to switch to BEV, H2EV or gasoline. Hauling those materials around the world, will need more ships in the sea, hauling batteries, new and used, will need more fuel too. Oil companies never get screwed by any means of fueling your car. Think about it.

snippet.textDisplay:
Happy I found this channel, the first part was like any good youtube car review, but the part where he argued with himself really nailed it. The battery vs hydrogen debate is so often dumbed down and people are not willing to yield and inch to the other side. Here he brought up so many of the arguments I wish was talked about more often. I think James has a very good point in that the future belongs to BOTH battery electric vehicles and hydrogen vehicles, or at least some form of fuel cell vehicle.


My prediction is that battery electric will dominate for the coming years but that as fuel cell technology gets cheaper and we have more hydrogen produced from renewables, you will see hydrogen vehicles more widely used. Possibly one may combine the hydrogen when CO2 to produce methane which is easier to store. The point is that I think semi-trucks, large ships, an potentially airplanes will use fuel cell technology and not batteries. Batteries will primarily be for regular cars. Hydrogen will likely gain ground as energy storage for the grid.


A big potential I think is producing massive quantities of clean hydrogen in say the Sahara dessert using electrolysis driven by large solar farms. Then gas pipes or compressed liquid gas tanks are used to ship it. Hydrogen is kind of a bad carries as it cannot be sent through regular gas pipes so I think there is a high chance we will simply convert that hydrogen to methane, ethanol or some other energy carrier which is more practical. With solid oxide fuel cells we can run a fuel cell directly on simply hydrocarbons such as methane and ethanol. You don't need hydrogen.
snippet.textOriginal:

The battery vs hydrogen debate is so often dumbed down and people are not willing to yield and inch to the other side. Here he brought up so many of the arguments I wish was talked about more often. I think James has a very good point in that the future belongs to BOTH battery electric vehicles and hydrogen vehicles, or at least some form of fuel cell vehicle.


My prediction is that battery electric will dominate for the coming years but that as fuel cell technology gets cheaper and we have more hydrogen produced from renewables, you will see hydrogen vehicles more widely used. Possibly one may combine the hydrogen when CO2 to produce methane which is easier to store. The point is that I think semi-trucks, large ships, an potentially airplanes will use fuel cell technology and not batteries. Batteries will primarily be for regular cars. Hydrogen will likely gain ground as energy storage for the grid.


A big potential I think is producing massive quantities of clean hydrogen in say the Sahara dessert using electrolysis driven by large solar farms.  Then gas pipes or compressed liquid gas tanks are used to ship it. Hydrogen is kind of a bad carries as it cannot be sent through regular gas pipes so I think there is a high chance we will simply convert that hydrogen to methane, ethanol or some other energy carrier which is more practical. With solid oxide fuel cells we can run a fuel cell directly on simply hydrocarbons such as methane and ethanol. You don't need hydrogen.

snippet.textDisplay: Hydrogen cars are pretty charming.  It's like learning about steam-powered cars from the earliest days of car tech.  You can't help but think they'd have stood a solid chance if they'd been pushed a decade or two earlier.  Personally, I expect hydrogen to achieve the closest thing to "success" in Japan, as nationalistic incentive dictates it brute-forces something of a market, before petering out for good.

snippet.textDisplay:
Sure, HFC makes sense with abundant clean energy. But that’s definitely not going to happen this side of 2050, if this century at all! It is absolutely a red herring argument, and Toyota knows it.

At least 99% can charge fast enough at home to replenish daily usage (a few would have to modernize their grid connection), and fast charging is already getting into 250 kW peak, making 15 minute charging sessions the norm on long trips.

If a country has a V2G-enabled BEV fleet it has a massive enough energy buffer to allow relying on renewable sources. What it can’t do is store a summer surplus for use in winter. Hydrogen can do that, but you would need three times the generation capacity since two thirds are lost in the inefficient chain, so if you “only” consume twice as much in winter, you are better off running on batteries at just 50% utilization in summer...

Maybe there are energy security reasons? Renewable energy is low power density and huge areas are needed for production. They’ll be easy military targets. Hydrogen could perhaps be stored deep underground for safekeeping? But I shudder to think about the accident potential of massive hydrogen stores.

The truth is it’s a massively complex problem abandoning fossil fuels — yet absolutely imperative that we do. HFC cars is a hindrance, not a help, precisely because that fundamental assumption, abundant clean energy, is nothing but a fantasy in the foreseeable future.
snippet.textOriginal:
Sure, HFC makes sense with abundant clean energy. But that’s definitely not going to happen this side of 2050, if this century at all! It is absolutely a red herring argument, and Toyota knows it.

At least 99% can charge fast enough at home to replenish daily usage (a few would have to modernize their grid connection), and fast charging is already getting into 250 kW peak, making 15 minute charging sessions the norm on long trips. 

If a country has a V2G-enabled BEV fleet it has a massive enough energy buffer to allow relying on renewable sources. What it can’t do is store a summer surplus for use in winter. Hydrogen can do that, but you would need three times the generation capacity since two thirds are lost in the inefficient chain, so if you “only” consume twice as much in winter, you are better off running on batteries at just 50% utilization in summer...

Maybe there are energy security reasons? Renewable energy is low power density and huge areas are needed for production. They’ll be easy military targets. Hydrogen could perhaps be stored deep underground for safekeeping? But I shudder to think about the accident potential of massive hydrogen stores.

The truth is it’s a massively complex problem abandoning fossil fuels — yet absolutely imperative that we do. HFC cars is a hindrance, not a help, precisely because that fundamental assumption, abundant clean energy, is nothing but a fantasy in the foreseeable future.

snippet.textDisplay: The Toyota is the better, safer car in my opinion.  I would be more inclined to purchase or lease the Toyota over the Tesla. That said I would never buy an Electric Car.  I have said it before Hydrogen is the Future for the Car.  Conversion of a Gasoline Engine is quite easy. Water Vapor in the End Waste Product. Also As Fuel Cell Technology improves it will surpass the Electric Vehicles. May understands European Drivers better than American Drivers outside of the Boston to Washington D.C. Corridor.  Texas, California, Alaska,  and the Fly Over States Hydrogen Will Be King.   Gasoline and Propane Powered Cars are still going to be the Norm for the Time Being. Also Natural Gas Powered Vehicles in America will become more prevalent since America is Sitting on a Vast Ocean of Natural Gas now due to Fracking.  America is Now Exporting Oil and Natural Gas to Europe and Japan.  All possible due to Fracking. The U.S. Continues to lower it's greenhouse gases annually and it is all due to Fracking and Natural Gas.  Not Legislation, or some Dumb Treaty Agreement.  China is the World's Largest Polluter followed by most Asian Countries then The Former Soviet Countries of Eastern Europe, with South and Central American Countries bringing up the rears. North Korea is a another major polluter.  Funny, The Capitalist Western Nations are The Most Energy Efficient and The Least Polluting.  Hmmm, So the Free Markets are actually Environmentally Friendly Compared to the Socialist Marxists Communist Countries of The World.  Imagine that.
